term: Canadian product-liability "duty-of-care" precedent case
definition:
Donoghue v. Stevenson - manufacturer owes reasonable care to end-user.

In Donoghue v. Stevenson, the court said that manufacturers must take reasonable care to make sure their products are safe for the people who use them.
This case created the rule that you can be held responsible if someone is hurt because you didn’t make your product safely—even if they didn’t buy it directly from you.

Example

A woman found a snail in her ginger beer and got sick.
She didn’t buy the drink herself, but the manufacturer was still held responsible.
Why? Because they had a duty of care to anyone who might drink their product.
This case showed that companies can’t ignore the end-user’s safety.
It helped shape the modern idea of negligence law.

term: Legal doctrine that says land-sale agreements must be in writing
definition:
Statute of Frauds.

The Statute of Frauds is a rule that says agreements to sell land must be written down to be legally valid. You can’t just rely on verbal promises when it comes to selling or buying land. If it’s not in writing, the deal usually won’t hold up in court. This protects people from fraud or confusion. It’s a way to make land deals clear and official.

Example:

Mark tells Lisa he’ll sell her a piece of land for $50,000, and she agrees—but they don’t write anything down. Later, Mark changes his mind. Because there’s no written contract, Lisa probably can’t force the sale. If they had written and signed an agreement, the Statute of Frauds would make it enforceable.

term: What question does the reasonable person test ask? And for which cases this test is being used?
definition:
Asks 'What would a reasonable person have done in the same circumstances?'

The reasonable person test is used in negligence cases to see if someone acted carefully enough.
It asks, “What would an average, careful person have done in the same situation?”
If the person didn’t act like that, they may be found negligent.

Example

A store owner doesn’t clean up a spilled drink, and a customer slips.
A court asks: Would a reasonable person have cleaned the spill quickly to prevent danger?
If yes, and the owner didn’t, that’s likely negligence.
The test helps decide if someone’s behavior was careless or acceptable.

term: Contract with a mandatory arbitration clause - can a party refuse and litigate instead?
definition:
No. Once signed, parties are bound; the court can even appoint an arbitrator if they cannot agree.

If you sign a contract with a mandatory arbitration clause, you can’t choose to go to court instead. You’ve already agreed to solve disputes through arbitration only. Even if both parties can’t pick an arbitrator, a court will assign one for them. So, once it’s signed, you’re stuck with arbitration. The court won’t let you skip it and sue instead.

Example:

Emma signs a contract to work on a project. It says all disputes must go to arbitration. Later, there's a disagreement, and Emma tries to sue the company in court. The court refuses because of the mandatory arbitration clause. Even if Emma and the company can’t agree on who should arbitrate, the court will pick someone. She must go through arbitration.

term: Cutting an employee's salary 20 % without consent is treated as what kind of termination?
definition:
Constructive dismissal - employee may treat contract as terminated and sue for severance/notice.

If a boss cuts someone’s salary by 20% without asking, that’s called constructive dismissal. Even though the person wasn’t directly fired, the change is so serious that the law sees it as a forced resignation. The employee can then quit and sue the employer as if they were fired. They may get severance pay or notice. It's like being pushed out without being told outright.
Example:

John’s boss suddenly cuts his salary from $60,000 to $48,000 without asking. John quits because he can’t accept that pay cut. Even though he resigned, the law sees it as if he was forced out. That’s constructive dismissal. Now, John can take legal action to get severance pay or notice compensation.

term: What is a passing-off action?
definition:
You must have a trademark (registered or common-law) that the public associates with your goods/services; mere similarity of un-trademarked trade names is not enough.

A passing-off action is when you sue someone for pretending to be your brand.
To win, you must prove you have a trademark (official or based on long-time use) that the public recognizes.
Just having a name that’s similar isn’t enough if you haven’t built a clear connection to it.

Example

You’ve run "Bella Bean Coffee" for 10 years, and locals know your name and logo.
Someone opens “Bella’s Beans” nearby with similar colors and fonts.
If you have a trademark, or the public already links your name to your business, you can sue for passing off.
But if your name isn’t well-known or protected, you likely won’t win just because it “sounds similar.”

term: Is the Criminal Code part of the Canadian Constitution?
definition:
No — it is a separate federal statute.


Think of the Constitution as the “rules of the entire game.”

The Canadian Constitution is the highest law in the whole country.
It tells us:

• how the government works
• what powers each level of government has
• your fundamental rights (like freedom of expression, equality rights)

This stuff is permanent, foundational, and hard to change.

The Criminal Code is just one law — a very big law — created by Parliament under the powers the Constitution grants.

It lists crimes and punishments.
Assault, fraud, theft, harassment, homicide — they all live there.

But the Criminal Code depends on the Constitution to exist.

Because the Constitution is supreme.
If part of the Criminal Code violates the Constitution, the courts can strike it down.

Example:
Let’s say you and I are playing soccer.

The Constitution = the official FIFA rules
(they define what soccer is, who can do what, and what limits exist)

The Criminal Code = your coach giving you team rules
(“Nima, don’t slide tackle from behind,”
“Nima, no fighting the referee,”
“Nima, if you kick someone in the face, you get benched.”)

The coach’s rules matter…
…but if the coach makes a rule that breaks FIFA rules, it gets thrown out.

Same thing:
Criminal Code must obey the Constitution.
Because the Constitution is the foundation — the sport itself.

term: What is Contra proferentem rule?
definition:
An ambiguous clause is read against the drafter and in favour of the other party.

If a contract has a confusing part, it will be interpreted against the person who wrote it.
This rule helps protect the other person, who didn’t create the unclear wording.
It encourages drafters to write clear and fair contracts.
So, if you’re the one writing, be careful—vague terms can backfire.
This rule is called "contra proferentem" and it favors the non-drafting side.

3) Example

Imagine a company writes a contract that says, “Service will be available in the evening,” but doesn’t define what “evening” means.
If a customer later complains that service wasn’t available at 6 PM, the court may side with the customer.
Why? Because the company wrote the contract and left it unclear.
So, the unclear term is used against the company.
This rule motivates people to be clear and precise when drafting contracts.
It’s about fairness and clarity.

term: What is the purpose of a comparative-negligence clause in a contract?
definition:
To fairly divide financial responsibility according to each party’s level of fault.

Example: 

Imagine a delivery company crashes into a store’s wall, but the store didn’t follow safety rules either. A comparative-negligence clause says the delivery driver is 70% at fault, and the store is 30% at fault. So, if damages cost $10,000, the driver (or their company) pays $7,000 and the store pays $3,000. Without this clause, one side might have to pay for everything, even if both were careless. This way, blame is shared fairly.

term: Biggest disadvantage of a sole proprietorship
definition:
Unlimited personal liability for debts and lawsuits.

In a sole proprietorship, the owner is the same as the business. If the business owes money or gets sued, the owner has to pay with their own money. This means they could lose personal things like their car, house, or savings. This is called unlimited personal liability, and it's the biggest risk of running a business alone. There's no legal protection for the owner's personal property.

Example:

Maria owns a bakery by herself. One day, a customer sues her because they got sick from her food. The court says Maria has to pay $100,000. But her bakery only has $20,000. Because of unlimited personal liability, Maria must pay the rest—$80,000—from her personal savings or even by selling her car or house.

term:
When can disability be a lawful ground for discrimination?

Example: A fire department needs firefighters to carry heavy equipment. Someone with a disability applies but can’t meet that physical requirement, even with special tools or modified duties.
Since lifting is a core part of the job, the department can lawfully reject the applicant.
This is discrimination, but it's allowed because the job has a bona-fide need.

(A bona-fide need is something that’s truly required, not just a preference. In jobs, it means a task or skill that is so important that the job can’t be done without it. It must be fair, necessary, and not made up to exclude people.)

(Accommodation means Adjustments or changes made to help someone with a disability do their job.)

term: Examples of Tort
definition: Example: Imagine Alex, an engineer, lies about a bridge's safety to win a contract—this fraud is an intentional tort. If Alex also walks onto a restricted construction site without permission, that's trespass. Later, Alex tells clients that another engineer is incompetent even though it isn't true; that's defamation. Each of these deliberate actions can lead the injured parties to sue Alex for damages under tort law. If Alex had simply mis-calculated a load because of sloppy math, that would be negligence, not an intentional tort.

term: Which code takes precedence if a technical-society code conflicts with a provincial code?
definition:
The provincial/territorial association’s Code of Ethics prevails.

If a national or technical group’s rules disagree with your local (provincial or territorial) ethics rules, you must follow the local code. That’s because the provincial code has legal authority in that region. Even if the technical society is well-known, its rules are secondary. Local rules override the others when they conflict. Always follow the provincial association’s Code of Ethics first.

Example:

Imagine you're an engineer in Alberta and follow both Engineers Canada’s and IEEE’s rules. If IEEE says it’s okay to accept gifts from clients but Alberta’s code says no gifts allowed, you must follow Alberta’s rule. Even though IEEE is a respected technical society, Alberta’s code is the law in your province. So the local rule wins in a conflict.

term: Site coordinator responsibility on large Alberta construction site
definition: Must protect all workers on site and anyone in the vicinity affected by site hazards.

term: Difference between 'environmental compliance' and 'sustainability'
definition:
Compliance = day-to-day legal minimum; sustainability = long-term strategy.

Environmental compliance is doing the required legal minimum each day to avoid violations.
Sustainability is a bigger, long-term plan to improve environmental and social outcomes.
Compliance = reactive (follow rules); sustainability = proactive (set goals, innovate).
Compliance answers “Are we legal?”; sustainability asks “Are we responsible and future-proof?”
You need compliance now, but sustainability guides the future.

3) Example

A factory installs filters to meet air emission limits — that’s compliance.
It then sets a goal to cut GHG emissions 50% by 2030, invests in renewables, and redesigns packaging — that’s sustainability.
Compliance prevents fines; sustainability earns trust and saves resources.
Compliance is checklists and permits; sustainability is targets and innovation.
Both matter, but they play different roles.

term: What is a Life-Cycle Analysis (LCA) inventory?

Judges a project's sustainability by listing all energy & resource inputs and all outputs (products & wastes) to determine the net result (overall environmental impact).

Inventory: a detailed list of items analyzed.

term: CPD-exemption request routinely accepted by Canadian associations
definition: Parental leave (temporary exemption, CPD resumes on return).

term: What's the difference between enforcement and discipline in engineering regulation?
definition:
Enforcement: Actions taken against non-members (unlicensed individuals) who unlawfully use protected titles or practise without authorization. Ensures only qualified persons offer engineering services.
Discipline: Actions taken against licensed members found guilty of professional misconduct or incompetence. May include fines, practice restrictions, suspension, or revocation of licence.

definition: Province/territory · Licence type · Name of licence holder · Licence number.

term: Copying unregistered software in Canada
definition: Copyright is automatic upon creation; registration is optional.

term: Overlap of law and ethics: What's the relationship?
definition: All criminal acts are unethical, but not all unethical acts are criminal.

term: Under Kant’s formalism, who is exempt from basic moral duties like honesty and fairness?
definition: No one. Duties are universal—every person must act in a correct ethical manner.

term: IP creation under contract

term: Bridge-design choice and Mill's utilitarianism

definition: Morals = personal beliefs; Ethics = shared societal principles.

definition: Ethical writing ≈ 3,000 years old; calculus and statistics date since 17th century.

term: What is a “secret commission” in professional ethics?
definition:
A hidden gift or “kickback” given (or received) to influence a decision—i.e., bribery (e.g., lavish gifts to secure a contract).

term: Duty to inform

term: Reporting dishonest conduct
definition: Reporting another practitioner's dishonest conduct is viewed as maintaining the honour and integrity of the profession.

term: Exceptions for disclosure
definition: The three standard exceptions that allow disclosure of client/employer confidential info are legal requirement, client/employer permission, or necessary to protect public safety.

term: Sale of Goods Act
definition:
The Sale of Goods Act implies three conditions that every product must satisfy: 1) Usability / fitness-for-purpose 2) Safety 3) Quality.

The Sale of Goods Act is a law that says all sold products must meet three basic standards: they must work properly (fit for their purpose), be safe to use, and be of good quality. Even if these rules aren’t written in a contract, they still apply automatically. If a product fails one of these, the buyer can ask for a refund or replacement. These protections are built into the sale by default.

Example:

Sara buys a kettle that doesn’t boil water, overheats, and breaks in two days. Under the Sale of Goods Act, she can return it. The kettle isn’t fit for purpose, isn’t safe, and lacks quality. Even if the store didn’t mention these rules, the law still protects Sara. She's entitled to a refund or new product.

term: Mill's Utilitarianism
definition: Selecting the option that brings the greatest good to the greatest number embodies Mill's Utilitarianism.

term: Finality vs. interpretation
definition: In codes & standards practice, 'finality' is the state a document reaches after the professional has applied all relevant codes & standards and it is ready for others to act on; 'interpretation' is the professional judgement used to select, understand, and apply those codes & standards correctly.

term: Improving communication skills
definition: The best way for a professional to improve poor communication skills is to pursue targeted Continuing Professional Development (CPD) activities.

term: Whistle-blowing report

term: Builders' (all-risk) insurance
definition: Covers property or structure under construction (materials, labour & partially completed work).

term: Duty-to-inform
definition: Before deviating from an approved design, a P.Eng. must tell the employer the consequences of the deviation on safety, cost, schedule, codes, etc.

term: Fukushima 2011 sequence
definition: Correct order: (1) Earthquake → (2) Automatic reactor shut-off → (3) Tsunami floods plant → (4) Nuclear meltdown.

term: 1982 Lodgepole (Alberta) blow-out
definition: Taught industry that the single most critical prevention measure on drill sites is rigid adherence to safe, standardized drilling & kick-control procedures.

term: Certified Engineering Technologist (C.E.T.)
definition: Only those who voluntarily complete provincial certification may call themselves this; right-to-practice is open to diploma holders, but right-to-title is protected.

term: Ownership of software created by an employee

term: What is the main purpose of a Communications-System Policy (CSP)?
definition:
Main purpose is to educate staff on risks/liabilities of digital communications (e.g., email, chat apps) & set acceptable-use rules for email, IM, etc.

A Communications-System Policy (CSP) tells staff how to safely and properly use work tools like email and messaging.
It teaches them about risks (like data leaks or lawsuits) and sets clear rules for what’s allowed.
The goal is to protect both the company and the employees.

Example

An employee sends a personal joke to a coworker over work email.
The CSP says email should only be used for business purposes.
It also warns that messages can be monitored and might be used in legal cases.
Because of the policy, the employee now knows to keep personal chats off work systems.
This prevents issues for them and the company.

term: Company name requirements
definition: Must include "Ltd./Inc./Corp." to signal to outsiders that liability is limited to corporate assets.

term: Software-development failure modes
definition: Technical failure (can't meet spec) and Service failure (system doesn't deliver required function) most threaten public safety.

term: Liability when design relied solely on software output
definition: P.Eng. remains fully liable; must rigorously check outputs - responsibility cannot be delegated to the program.

term: Unlicensed person offering structural-design software & support in Alberta
definition: Selling software is OK, but providing engineering design/consulting services requires a licence/permit.

term: Whistle-blowing anonymity rule for Canadian P.Eng./P.Geo.
definition: Must identify themselves and be ready to participate; regulator keeps identity confidential only as far as case allows - no fully anonymous reports.

term: Whistle-blowing channel required by Canadian engineering Codes of Ethics

term: Client insists on ignoring engineer's structural-safety recommendation - engineer's correct response
definition: Explain the risks in plain language and withdraw from the work; do not assist or supervise unsafe construction.

term: Professional liability (E&O) insurance in Canada: where & for whom is it most critical?
definition: Mandatory only in some provinces and especially essential for practitioners in private practice, who have the highest lawsuit exposure.

term: Due-diligence defence factors (foreseeability / preventability / controllability / correctability): which is not considered?
definition: Correctability - courts focus on what could be foreseen, prevented or controlled before harm occurred.

term: Purpose of a Failure Modes & Effects Analysis (FMEA)
definition: Systematically list each component/assembly, identify how it can fail, and trace the effect of that failure on the larger system.

term: Scope of a designer's hazard analysis — what uses must be considered?
definition: Normal use, foreseeable misuse, and failures - all potential hazards must be addressed.

term: When a design hazard (e.g., exposed blade) is essential and cannot be removed, professional obligation?
definition: Warn users and provide effective shielding/guards to protect public safety.

term: Three classic grounds for a product-liability lawsuit
definition: 1. Defective manufacture 2. Negligent design 3. Failure to warn of inherent dangers.

term: Difference in focus: building codes vs standards
definition: Codes prescribe how to construct/install; standards set minimum quality & uniformity requirements.

term: Professional duty when industry codes are "very low" or outdated
definition: Exceed the minimum; engineer must raise the level of care to ensure reliability & safety.

term: Best way to keep a proprietary manufacturing process secret
definition: Use employment contracts with strong confidentiality (non-disclosure) clauses rather than patents or trademarks.

term: Obligation when reviewing another professional's work
definition: Inform the original professional of the review before starting, even if the employer requested it.

term: What should you do if a project goes beyond your competence?
definition:
Seek qualified assistance immediately; do not delay the client's project while you retrain (NPPE III.3).

If a job goes beyond your skills, you must get qualified help right away.
Don’t try to handle it alone or delay the client’s work while you retrain.
The priority is protecting the client and doing the work properly and safely.

Example

An engineer is asked to design a complex electrical system but only has experience with mechanical design.
Instead of trying to figure it out slowly or saying yes and hoping for the best, they call in an electrical expert.
This keeps the project moving and avoids mistakes.
The engineer can learn more later, but the client’s project must not suffer in the meantime.

term: Peer sealing work they did not supervise

term: Research scientist vs. Engineer core roles
definition: Research scientist generates new knowledge; engineer applies that knowledge (NPPE III.3).

term: Natural greenhouse effect importance

term: Required environmental literacy for P.Eng./P.Geo.

definition: 1️⃣ Gas emissions → 2️⃣ Enhanced greenhouse effect → 3️⃣ Global warming → 4️⃣ Climate change (NPPE III.6).

myth : AFSANE

term: What does McGregor’s Theory Y assume about employees?

Perform at least one hand calculation on a simplified case and compare it to the software output to ensure accuracy.

term:
Collegial (Theory Y) management style: How do staff operate, and what is the manager's role?

definition:

term: What does a Commercial General Liability (CGL) policy cover for engineering businesses?
definition:
Third-party bodily injury (BI) and property damage (PD).

Commercial General Liability (CGL)
A type of insurance that protects businesses if someone else gets hurt or their property is damaged because of the business’s operations.

A CGL policy helps engineering businesses if someone outside the company gets hurt or has their property damaged because of the company’s work. It doesn’t cover damage to the company’s own things—just problems caused to others. This is important because it protects the business from lawsuits and big bills if accidents happen during a project or at the office.

Imagine an engineering company is visiting a client’s building, and one of their tools falls and injures someone—that’s bodily injury. Or maybe they accidentally damage a server room, causing expensive problems—property damage. In both cases, the CGL insurance would help pay for legal costs or compensation. That way, the business doesn't have to pay out of pocket.

term: Indigenous-reserve projects: why can't you finance by mortgage?

term: Canadian law that governs how private-sector firms collect, use & disclose personal data

term: When can an engineer/geoscientist file a construction lien?
definition:
Allowed if the engineer/geoscientist is a prime consultant (not merely a sub-consultant).

An engineer or geoscientist can file a lien to claim unpaid money only if they were hired as the main consultant (called a prime consultant). If they worked under someone else (like a sub-consultant), they can’t file a lien. The right to file a lien is for those who are directly responsible to the client. This helps protect primary contractors, not every person involved.

Example:

Jane is an engineer hired directly by a building owner to manage the whole project. If she doesn’t get paid, she can file a lien on the property to get her money. But Sam, who worked under Jane doing only part of the work, cannot file a lien himself. Only Jane has that legal right, since she is the prime consultant.

term: Must money always change hands to form a contract?

term: Sexual-harassment cases are heard where, and how broadly is harassment defined?

term: What offence involves buying shares based on confidential test results, and under which law is it prohibited?

term: What does federal law require when a project may affect Indigenous rights on claimed land?
definition:
Duty rests on the Crown (government) for any project on claimed land, proven or unproven.

Example

Let’s say the government wants to build a pipeline through a forest. An Indigenous group says that land is part of their traditional territory, even if no court has officially confirmed it yet. The government still has a duty to talk with them, listen to their concerns, and possibly change the plan to reduce harm. That’s consultation and accommodation, and it's the government’s job, not the company’s.

term: Accurate description of force majeure clause

term: What must a consultant and client do under Qualifications-Based Selection (QBS) for scope?

term: Subsurface anchors installed without consent on a neighbour's land
definition:
Is it trespass? Yes. Property rights extend below and above the surface; unauthorized encroachment is trespass even if harmless.

Yes, it is trespass if you install things like anchors underground on someone else’s land without their permission. Property rights don’t just cover the surface—they go above and below the ground too. Even if the anchor doesn’t cause any damage, it’s still illegal. The law says unauthorized use is trespassing, no matter how harmless it seems. You always need the owner’s consent.

Example:

A contractor installs anchors underground that extend into a neighbour’s property. The anchors are hidden and don’t cause any harm. But the neighbour didn’t agree to it. Even though nothing is damaged, the contractor has trespassed. The neighbour could legally demand removal or sue for it.

term: In Canadian tort law, what is a professional’s “duty to warn”?
definition: An obligation to warn about impending damage or injury to people or property when aware (or reasonably foreseeable). It applies even if the hazard isn’t in your scope—you must take steps to warn/prevent harm.

term: For liability in tort, the defendant's act must be ___ or ___
definition: Intentional or negligent.

definition: They cannot be used as evidence in any later court or arbitration proceedings.

S.C.R. Short for Supreme Court Reports — the official record of decisions by Canada’s Supreme Court.)
definition: It’s the volume number of the Supreme Court Reports (not a chapter).

term:
Why is construction litigation often slow and costly?

Litigation: the process of resolving disputes in court
Specs: short for "specifications," the detailed description of work and materials
definition:
Because it typically involves many stakeholders (owners, general contractors, subcontractors, suppliers) plus massive volumes of technical records—drawings, specs (detailed requirements), emails—that lawyers must painstakingly review.

Example:A delay dispute on a high-rise can drag on 12 months when counsel from the owner, GC and three subs pore over 10,000 emails and 800 CAD drawings—each page adding hours of billable time.

term: Which court handles cases related to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?
definition:
The Supreme Court of Canada.

Here is the relation between the Charter and the Constitution:
The Charter is the part of the Constitution that protects your basic rights.

Think of the Constitution as the foundation of the whole Canadian legal house.
Inside that house, the Charter is the room where all your rights and freedoms live.

term: Harris, Pritchard & Rabins 'Golden Rule' for engineers abroad
definition: Professionals should not impose their own choices on local people.

term: Liability of Partners in a General Partnership-What liability do partners face for partnership debts and wrongful acts?
definition:
▪️ Definition: In a general partnership, all partners are jointly and severally liable for the firm's debts and any wrongful acts, even if they didn't cause them.
▪️ Meaning of "jointly and severally": Each partner can be held responsible both together (jointly) and on their own (severally) for the entire obligation.
▪️ Example: The partnership owes a supplier $50 000. The supplier can sue Partner A alone for the full $50 000, or any other partner, regardless of who actually ordered the goods.

term: Negligence, contracts, insurance across Canada's systems
definition: Basic principles are fairly consistent in both systems; differences seldom affect normal engineering practice.

term: Quebec Civil Code on contract interpretation
definition: Code says common intention prevails over literal text.

term: Three elements of Canada's Constitution

term: What is mediator confidentiality in dispute resolution?
definition:
Definition: All communications (written or spoken) shared with the mediator during a mediation are legally privileged, meaning they cannot be disclosed or used later in arbitration or court.
Key term: Privileged - protected by law from being revealed as evidence.
Example: In private caucus, Company A admits it overlooked a safety risk. That admission stays in mediation and can't be brought into a later lawsuit.

term: 10% bid bond
definition: Guarantees that the winning bidder will enter into the contract and supply performance security; if the bidder backs out, the surety pays the owner up to the bond amount (typically 10% of the bid).

term: What is Governing-law clause?
definition:
Definition: A governing-law clause is a part of a contract that tells which state or country's laws will be used to decide any arguments about the deal. It helps everyone know in advance where to go and what rules to follow if they disagree. By choosing a specific jurisdiction, the parties reduce surprises and legal costs. This clause appears near the end of most agreements. It's especially important in deals crossing borders.
Key term: Jurisdiction → the legal authority or region whose courts and laws apply.
Example: "Imagine two companies—one in California and one in Germany—signing a sales contract. They include a governing-law clause saying California law will apply. Later, they disagree over payment terms. Both sides then know they must ask a California court to interpret the contract. This saves time debating which country's rules to use. It makes the legal process clearer and faster."
Persian (Farsi): BANDE GHANOON-E HAKEM!

term: Forum/venue clause
definition: States which courts will hear any dispute in multi-country deals.

term: What is a no-damages-for-delay clause in a construction contract?
definition:
Blocks a contractor from claiming extra "damages" (compensation) for delays they cause, but doesn't stop claims if the owner orders a shutdown.

• Example: If a crew miss-schedule causes a week's delay, the contractor gets no extra pay. But if the owner suspends work for permits, the contractor can recover added costs.

term: What is a per-diem rate and when is it best used?
definition:
Definition: A fixed daily fee paid to a consultant ("per diem" = "per day").
Use it when: The project's scope or hours can't be accurately predicted—gives cost certainty and flexibility.
Example: Hiring a site manager at $800/day, whether they oversee 1 task or 10 tasks in a day.

term: What is quantum meruit and when can you use it?
definition:
Definition: Latin for "as much as deserved." Allows you to recover a reasonable value for services and materials when no formal contract exists but the work was accepted.
Example: You clear a flooded basement in an emergency without a contract; the homeowner benefits and refuses to pay—so you sue on quantum meruit to get paid fairly.

term: Occupational Health & Safety Act
definition: Employers must provide — and workers must help maintain — a safe, healthy workplace.

term: What is the standard term of copyright protection in Canada?
definition: Copyright lasts for the life of the creator plus 70 years.

term: Human Rights Code

term: Loser-Pays Cost Rule-What is it, and why does it matter?
definition:
▪️ Definition: A rule in many legal systems where the party that loses a lawsuit must pay a portion (or all) of the winning party's legal costs.
▪️ Purpose: Deters frivolous or weak claims by adding a financial consequence for the loser.
▪️ Example:Acme Corp sues Beta Ltd over a minor contract ambiguity. The court finds in Beta's favor and orders Acme to pay Beta's legal fees. Acme thinks twice before filing similar baseless suits in the future.

term: Workers'-comp premiums

term: Arbitration in construction contracts

term: Entering the U.S. as a Canadian engineer under CUSMA/USMCA

term: What is a change order?
definition:
A change order is basically a small written update to the contract when something changes during the project.
Think of it as a receipt that says:

how much extra work is being added

or how much work is being removed (a credit)

and what the new total contract price becomes.

It’s simple, but important. Without a change order, arguments explode later about “who agreed to what.”
So it acts like a financial bookmark that keeps everyone honest.

Analogy:
Imagine you’re at a barbershop.
You ask for a haircut ($30), but halfway through you say, “Can you also trim my beard?” The barber says, “That’s $10 extra.”
A change order is the written note that says:
“Haircut $30 + Beard trim $10 = $40 total.”
No surprises. No fights.

term: Key difference: Québec Civil Code vs. Common-law courts
definition: Civil Code puts less weight on case precedent; Common Law relies on it heavily.

What's the golden rule for expert witness testimony?

term: What is a material mistake in contract law?
definition:
A material mistake is a significant error about a fact central to the contract that existed when the agreement was made, allowing the mistaken party to void the contract.

Example: Alice buys what she believes is an original painting. After signing, she learns it's a cheap replica. Because authenticity was essential, she can cancel the deal.

Difficult word:
Voidable - able to be legally canceled or undone by one party.

term: Doctrine of Estoppel-What stops a party from enforcing strict contract terms after they've let the other side ignore them?
definition:
A legal rule that prevents someone from insisting on a strict contract right if they previously waived it or led the other side to believe they would be lenient.

Example: A landlord accepts late rent for months without penalty. Later, they cannot suddenly enforce a late‐fee for those same missed due dates.

Difficult word:Waive - to voluntarily give up a right.

term: Committee membership restriction: Can you serve on both the Investigation (Complaints) Committee and the Discipline Committee?(Investigation Committee - gathers and reviews complaints; Discipline Committee - holds formal hearings)
definition:
No - you may join only one committee at a time, ensuring the investigative and disciplinary stages stay independent and impartial.

You can’t be on both the Investigation and Discipline Committees at the same time.
This rule helps make sure that fact-finding and decision-making stay separate.
The idea is to keep the process fair, with no one person influencing both steps.
You must choose one role—either help investigate or help decide punishment.
It avoids conflict of interest and keeps everything neutral.

Example:

Imagine you're part of a school panel.
If you help gather facts about a cheating case, you shouldn’t also decide the punishment.
Why? Because you might be biased from already seeing the evidence.
So, one group checks the facts, and another group decides what to do.
That’s why you can only join one committee—it keeps things honest and fair.
This way, no one has too much power in the process.

term: Legally enforceable part of a patent
definition:
The Claims section - it defines the protected features of the invention.

The claims section of a patent is the only part that’s legally protected. It lists the specific features of the invention that others can’t copy. If someone breaks those rules, the inventor can sue them. Other parts of the patent explain things, but only the claims can be enforced in court.

Example:

An inventor patents a new type of water filter. The patent has drawings and descriptions, but the claims section says, “a filter with a triple-layer mesh and a carbon core.” If someone else makes a filter with that same setup, the inventor can take legal action. Only what's in the claims is legally protected.

Alex invents a new type of phone charger and gets a patent. In the Claims section, he describes the exact design and how it works. Another company copies his design. Because it’s covered in his patent claims, Alex can sue them for infringement. The claims define his legal rights.

term: What triggers the requirement for a prime contractor under Canadian Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) regulations for a construction project?

The requirement for a prime contractor is triggered when two or more employers work simultaneously at a construction site. The prime contractor, designated in the contract, coordinates and ensures the safety of employees and the public. If not specified, the owner assumes this role.

Example: A site with a plumbing and framing contractor requires a prime contractor to manage safety, like ensuring fall protection. (Syllabus topic I.2, Ethics 5th ed. p.146 or 6th ed. p.145)

term: What is a tort?
definition:
A civil wrong where someone’s actions (or carelessness) cause harm to another person, and the injured person can sue for compensation instead of criminal punishment.

A tort happens when one person hurts another person or their property, even if it wasn’t on purpose.
It’s not a crime, so no one goes to jail — but the injured person can sue for money to make up for their loss.
Torts cover things like accidents (negligence), defamation, or trespassing.
It’s part of civil law, not criminal law.
In short: a tort means “you hurt me — now fix it with money.”

term: What is a letter of intent (LOI)?

short note showing intent to sign a full contract later.

A letter of intent is like saying, “I’m serious about this deal, but we’re not signing the final contract yet.”
It shows someone’s interest and commitment, but without all the final details locked in.
It’s often used in business, jobs, or big projects to start things off.
Think of it like a promise to keep talking and move forward.
It’s not legally binding (usually), but it shows you’re not just window-shopping.
It helps get everyone on the same page before the real contract.

term: After ADR uncovers professional misconduct
definition:
ADR stops and a formal complaint goes to the regulator to protect the public.

If ADR finds signs of professional misconduct, the process stops right away.
Instead of continuing the dispute, a formal complaint is sent to the regulator.
This is done to protect the public from harm and hold the professional accountable.

Example

During a mediation, a client reveals their accountant faked tax documents.
Because that’s professional misconduct, the ADR process ends.
A complaint is filed with the accounting board.
The board investigates and may suspend the accountant’s license.
This step puts public safety before finishing the private dispute.

term: Allowed ways to end a contract after contractor's fundamental breach
definition:
(1) Keep contractor & sue for damages or (2) Terminate & sue for damages.

If a contractor seriously breaks the contract (called a fundamental breach), you have two options:

Continue with the contractor but ask the court for money to cover your losses.

End the contract completely and then go to court to get money for the damage.
These are the legal choices available when the contractor does something really wrong that ruins the deal.

Example:

Let’s say a contractor was hired to build a swimming pool, but they used the wrong materials and made it unsafe.
As the client, you could keep the contractor to fix it but ask for money for the problems.
Or, you could cancel the contract and sue them to pay for the damages and hire someone else.
Both ways are allowed if the mistake is big enough.
A small mistake wouldn’t count—it has to be serious.
This protects you if the contractor really messes up.

term:
Which of the following is NOT a role performed by technical societies in Canada?

A) Providing technical resources such as journals, conferences, and training
B) Supporting professional development and networking
C) Developing technical standards in specialized fields
D) Licensing engineers and geoscientists to legally practice
definition:
D) Licensing engineers and geoscientists to legally practice

When we talk about technical societies (like IEEE, ASME, CSCE, CIM, etc.), their job is to support the technical growth of professionals. They publish journals, host conferences, set technical standards, and help engineers learn new things.

But they do NOT have any legal power.

They cannot:

• Give you a licence
• Allow you to legally call yourself P.Eng. or P.Geo.
• Discipline you for unethical behaviour
• Give you permission to practise engineering or geoscience

Those powers belong only to provincial/territorial regulators (like APEGA, EGBC, PEO, Engineers Geoscientists Manitoba, etc.). Regulators exist because engineering and geoscience affect public safety, so the government gives these regulators legal authority.

Think of it this way, Nima:
A technical society is like a gym — a place to train, practice, connect, and get better.
A regulator is like the government licensing office — the place that decides who is legally allowed to drive.

term: What does “per diem” pay mean, and when is it useful?

(Example

A consultant is hired for a project with no set end date.
Instead of guessing the total cost, the company offers $400 per diem.
That means the consultant gets $400 each day they work.
If they work 3 days, they earn $1,200.
This method keeps things simple while the project details are still unclear.
It’s like saying, “We’ll pay you daily while we figure things out.)

term: Commercial General Liability vs. Errors & Omissions insurance

CGL insurance protects you if someone is hurt or their property is damaged because of your work.

But if someone trips over your equipment at the site and breaks a leg, CGL handles that.

They cover different kinds of risks, and one doesn’t replace the other.

term: Hartford Coliseum (1978) lesson
definition:
Negligence: engineers relied only on computer analysis; should have cross-checked with hand methods (e.g., Euler buckling).

In the 1978 Hartford Coliseum collapse, engineers relied only on computers and didn’t double-check their work using basic hand calculations like Euler buckling. This was considered negligence because a good engineer should always verify computer results manually to catch errors. The lesson here: technology helps, but it doesn’t replace engineering judgment.

Example:

An engineer uses software to check if a roof design is safe. The software says everything’s fine, but the engineer doesn’t do any simple hand checks. Later, the roof collapses under its own weight because the software missed a critical issue. If the engineer had done a basic Euler buckling calculation, the weakness would’ve been clear. This kind of oversight is what happened at the Hartford Coliseum — and it’s a classic case of why human checks matter.

term: Relationship between statutes and the Constitution
definition:
Statutes must be compatible with the Constitution or they're invalid.

All laws (statutes) must follow the Constitution, which is the top law of the country. If a law goes against the Constitution, it is not valid. Courts can strike down or cancel such laws. This ensures all laws respect basic rights and rules set by the Constitution. No law can be higher than it.

Example:

Suppose a province makes a law that limits free speech. If that law goes against the freedom of expression guaranteed by the Constitution, a court can say the law is invalid. Even though it was passed properly, it doesn’t count because it violates the Constitution.

Additional note:
The Supreme Court of Canada is the main interpreter of the Constitution. When there’s a dispute about what the Constitution means or if a law breaks it, the Supreme Court makes the final decision. The court’s rulings help shape and apply the Constitution in real life. Its decisions are binding—everyone must follow them. So, the Constitution gives the rules, and the Supreme Court explains how to use them.

Example:

If a law is passed that limits freedom of religion, people might argue it violates the Constitution. The case could go to the Supreme Court. The judges would study the Constitution, especially the Charter of Rights, and decide if the law is allowed. Their ruling becomes the official interpretation of that part of the Constitution.

The Supreme Court of Canada is the court that most often makes final decisions about cases involving the Charter of Rights & Freedoms. It looks at whether laws or actions by the government violate Canadians’ rights. Once the Supreme Court decides, its ruling is final and must be followed across Canada. It acts like the top referee in legal disputes about rights.

Example:

A law in a province limits public protests. Someone challenges it, saying it violates the freedom of expression in the Charter. The case goes through lower courts and finally reaches the Supreme Court of Canada. The Supreme Court decides the law is unconstitutional. That ruling applies nationwide and can’t be appealed further.

Example: A 1980 ruling on pesticide liability may be set aside today if newer statutes change industry standards or scientific evidence shows different health risks.

term: Is unequal pay for the same job always illegal discrimination?

term: Easement
definition:
A legal right allowing someone to use another person's land for a specific purpose.
An easement is like a permission slip that lets one person use part of another person's property without owning it. It gives a specific right—for example, to walk, drive, or run a utility line—over land they don't own. Easements stay with the land, so if the property is sold, the new owner still has that right. They help neighbors avoid conflicts by clearly laying out who can do what on which parts of the land.

Jane owns a house behind Tom's house and needs to walk across Tom's yard to reach the public sidewalk. Tom grants Jane an easement allowing her to use that path anytime. Jane doesn't own Tom's yard—she only has the right to walk along that path. If Jane sells her house, the new owner also keeps that walking right. Without the easement, Jane might have to build a costly private sidewalk or negotiate access each time.

Example

Two coworkers are mediating a scheduling conflict. In her opening statement, Alex says she needs mornings for childcare and wants a fair rotation. Jordan’s opening statement explains he covers most early shifts and wants balance. Then they begin a joint discussion with the mediator. They clarify priorities and constraints. They consider a rotating schedule that splits mornings evenly.

term: What is a 10% bid bond?

If the bidder backs out, the surety pays the owner up to the bond amount (typically 10% of the bid).
This protects the owner from costs and delays caused by a no-show contractor.
It encourages serious, reliable bids.

Example

A contractor bids $500,000 on a project with a 10% bid bond.
They win, but refuse to sign the contract.
The surety must pay the owner up to $50,000 (10% of $500,000).
The owner uses this money to cover the extra cost of hiring the next bidder.
Because of the bond, the owner isn’t left completely exposed.

You do not have to pay for or make up the missed years—they are not retro-billed.

5. Lawful Purpose - The contract's goal must be legal.

Example: You offer $200 for a friend to paint your room, they accept, both intend a binding deal, you'll pay $200 (consideration), you're both adults (capacity), and painting is legal (lawful purpose).

term: What is estoppel in contract law?

term: difference between voiding and breaching the contract
definition:
✅ 1. Breaching a Contract (the simpler one)

A breach happens when one party breaks a valid contract.

The contract is real, legal, and enforceable…
…but someone fails to do what they promised.

Examples of breach:

A contractor doesn’t finish the work.

An engineer misses deadlines or delivers poor-quality work.

An owner doesn’t pay.

When a contract is breached, the innocent party can usually:

ask for damages (money),

end the contract,

or sometimes force performance.

Key idea:
The contract is valid, but someone broke it.

✅ 2. Voiding a Contract (very different)

To void a contract means the contract is treated as if it never legally existed at all.

It’s not “broken.”
It’s invalid — like a fake driver’s licence.

A contract may be void or voidable if:

one party was misled (misrepresentation)

there was no capacity (mental incapacity, minors)

there was duress or coercion

the subject of the contract is illegal

the contract is missing essential elements (like no consideration)

When a contract is void, nobody can enforce it.

Key idea:
A void contract is not legally real, so nobody can “breach” it.

🧠 Think of it like this:
Breach = The rulebook is valid, but a player broke the rules.
Void = The rulebook itself was fake or invalid from the start.
🌰 Nima-Friendly Analogy

Imagine you and a contractor sign a contract to build a deck at your house.

Scenario 1 — Breach (the contract is real):

Contractor agrees to build your deck but disappears halfway through.
He breached the contract.
You can sue him for damages because the contract was valid.

Scenario 2 — Void (the contract never legally existed):

The contractor turns out to be unlicensed, lied about qualifications, and forged documents to get the job.
Your contract is void — it’s like signing a deal with someone who pretended to be a doctor.
It was never valid from the beginning.
